specJson.name: brightics.function.regression$linear_regression_train
specJson.label: Linear Regression Train
specJson.description:
Linear regression attempts to model the relationship between a scalar variable and one or more explanatory variables by fitting a linear equation to observed data. For example, one might want to relate the weights of individuals to their heights using a linear regression model.

Linear regression was the first type of regression analysis to be studied rigorously, and to be used extensively in practical applications. This is because models which depend linearly on their unknown parameters are easier to fit than models which are non-linearly related to their parameters and because the statistical properties of the resulting estimators are easier to determine.

Reference
+ <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_regression>
+ <http://www.stat.yale.edu/Courses/1997-98/101/linreg.htm>
+ <https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.linear_model.LinearRegression.html>

params.label: Feature Columns
params.description: Feature column names. Only values in numeric type are possible.

params.label: Label column
params.description: The column designated for the labels of data. It should be numeric type as it is for regression.

params.label: Fit Intercept
params.description:
Whether to calculate the intercept for this model. If set to False, no intercept will be used in calculations (i.e. data is expected to be centered).
   - Available Options : `True`, `False`

params.label: VIF
params.description:
Whether to use the VIF method for feature selection to remove multicollinearity. VIF quantifies the severity of multicollinearity in an ordinary least squares regression analysis.
   - Available Options : `True`, `False`

params.label: VIF Threshold
params.description: If each feature's VIF value is greater than `VIF Threshold`, the model doen't use that feature to predict. This option is available only if `VIF` is set to True.

specJson.summary: This function trains a linear regression model.

md:
# Linear Regression Train This function trains a linear regression model. ## Description Linear regression attempts to model the relationship between a scalar variable and one or more explanatory variables by fitting a linear equation to observed data. For example, one might want to relate the weights of individuals to their heights using a linear regression model. Linear regression was the first type of regression analysis to be studied rigorously, and to be used extensively in practical applications. This is because models which depend linearly on their unknown parameters are easier to fit than models which are non-linearly related to their parameters and because the statistical properties of the resulting estimators are easier to determine. Reference + + + ## Properties ### VA #### INPUT 1. **table***: (Table) Training data in a Table. It must contain at least one column for labels. #### OUTPUT 1. **model** : (Model) Trained Linear Regression model. #### PARAMETER 1. **Feature Columns***: Feature column names. Only values in numeric type are possible. 2. **Label column***: The column designated for the labels of data. It should be numeric type as it is for regression. 3. **Fit Intercept**: Whether to calculate the intercept for this model. If set to False, no intercept will be used in calculations (i.e. data is expected to be centered). * Available Options : `True`, `False` 4. **VIF**: Whether to use the VIF method for feature selection to remove multicollinearity. VIF quantifies the severity of multicollinearity in an ordinary least squares regression analysis. * Available Options : `True`, `False` 5. **VIF Threshold**: If each feature's VIF value is greater than `VIF Threshold`, the model doen't use that feature to predict. This option is available only if `VIF` is set to True. 6. **Group By**: Columns to group by. ### Python #### USAGE ``` linear_regression_train(table, feature_cols, label_col, fit_intercept=True, is_vif=True, vif_threshold=10, group_by=None) ``` #### INPUT 1. **table***: (Table) Training data in a Table. It must contain at least one column for labels. #### OUTPUT 1. **model** : (Model) Trained Linear Regression model. #### PARAMETER 1. **feature_cols***: Feature column names. Only values in numeric type are possible. * Type: *list[str]* 2. **label_col***: The column designated for the labels of data. It should be numeric type as it is for regression. * Type: *str* 3. **fit_intercept**: Whether to calculate the intercept for this model. If set to False, no intercept will be used in calculations (i.e. data is expected to be centered). * Type: *bool* * Default / Range: True 4. **is_vif**: Whether to use the VIF method for feature selection to remove multicollinearity. VIF quantifies the severity of multicollinearity in an ordinary least squares regression analysis. * Type: *bool* * Default / Range: False 5. **vif_threshold**: If each feature's VIF value is greater than `vif_threshold`, the model doen't use that feature to predict. This option is available only if `is_vif` is set to True. * Type: *float* * Default / Range: 10 (1 <= value) 6. **group_by**: Columns to group by. * Type: *list[str]* ## Example ### VA **[Related Tutorial]** **[Sample Model]**
In this tutorial workflow, sample_iris data is used to train a linear regression. The generated model is afterward applied to a test data set to predict the value of _petal\_width_ , by using Linear Regression Predict function. The parameter settings used in the function are shown below. ##### ++Parameters++ 1. **Feature Columns*** : sepal_length, sepal_width 2. **Label Column*** : petal_width 3. **Fit Intercept** : True 4. **VIF** : True 5. **VIF Threshold** : 10 6. **Group By** : None ### Python ``` from brightics.function.regression import linear_regression_train input_table = inputs[0] result = linear_regression_train(table=input_table, feature_cols=['sepal_length', 'sepal_width'], label_col='petal_width', fit_intercept=True, is_vif=True, vif_threshold=10, group_by=None) output = result['model'] ```
In this python script, sample_iris data is used to train a linear regression. The generated model is afterward applied to a test data set to predict the value of _petal\_width_ , by using Linear Regression Predict function.
